title.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work North Star Alliance

description.narrative: Hands Off II partners work to reduce violence against sex workers at community, national and regional level. Outcomes of North Star Alliance include increased access to and use of services for sex workers, as well as a more enabling environment for sex work.

North Star Alliance provides health services to sex workers at Road Wellness Clinics along the transport corridor. Under Hands Off North Star Alliance will continue to increase access to sex workers and build an inclusive, health-literate sex worker community. Peer educators will mobilise their peers to visit the clinic, and work with nurses to stimulate sex workers to make safe and healthy choices. Influential community member gathered in Crisis Response Teams will work to reduce stigma from the community and provide support to sex workers who experienced violence.

Structural barriers such as stigma, discrimination and criminalisation hinder sex workers to access comprehensive rights based services. In many cases sex workers rely on public health services, however these are often inaccessible for sex workers located outside of the urban areas.

The programme’s primary target group is female, male and transgender sex workers, meaning those who receive money or goods in exchange for sexual services, either regularly or occasionally. North Star Alliance also works with influential community leaders.

mailing-address.narrative: Aidsfonds - Soa Aids Nederland, Condensatorweg 54, 1014 AX Amsterdam

title.narrative: Long term outcome 1.2

description.narrative: A national sex worker movements is functional and sustainable

title.narrative: Sex workers across the country report to be affiliated with a strong functional and sustainable national movement

description.narrative: To identify the common understanding of profession and rights across sex workers as well as monitor how sex workers inspire, inform and motivate each other.

comment.narrative: SANAC meeting with all stakeholders working with SWs
This is achieved through the CRT platforms where North Star gets to engage with other SW led organisations / SW service providers so there is a shared understanding of activities and collaborations.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.2

description.narrative: Empowered police officers have improved behaviour towards SWs and KPs

title.narrative: Self-reported changes in knowledge, attitude and behaviour towards sex workers by the police

description.narrative: To identify if police sensitisation and engagement leads to improved practice and attitude of police officers towards sex workers (female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers) and other key populations.

comment.narrative: No activities were done to meet this target due to lockdown restrictions.

Police sensitisation and engagment will be conducted during Q3 and Q4 - it is somewhat delayed due to the police priorities being directed towards lockdown restrictions and limited availability to other priorities.

title.narrative: Overall programme long term outcome 2

description.narrative: Increased access to, and use of inclusive services for seks workers

title.narrative: Sex workers report to have access to quality sex worker-friendly services

description.narrative: To assess if sex workers are satisfied with the services provided to them and if those services are in line with (inter)national standards based on the needs of sex workers. These needs can be different for female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers. This indicator covers health services, psychosocial services and legal and justice services for all sex workers.

comment.narrative: This hasn’t been achieved due to lockdown restrictions, however it is planned for Q3 and Q4 as we are able to access more SWs across the various focus groups.
We were not able to carry out customer satisfaction survey due to lockdown restrictions.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.1

description.narrative: Policies and laws are supportive of the wellbeing of sex workers

title.narrative: Self-reported changes in knowledge, attitude and behaviour towards sex workers by community leaders

description.narrative: To identify if community leader sensitisation and engagement leads to improved attitude of community leaders (traditional and religious leaders) towards sex workers and other key populations, regardless of their gender.

comment.narrative: No activities were done to meet this target due to lockdown restrictions.
This activity is planned and will be conducted in Q3 and Q4.

Out of the five supported sites (Ngodwana, Vic Falls, Beitbridge, Cato Ridge and Inchope), 187 SWs in this age catagory were reached. Data was extracted from the following data sources (ONA, violence reporting database). 84 SWs reported violence to law enforcement. Almost 55% SWs are not reporting violence to law enforcement, we plan to find out the reasons why the non reporting is so high.
we have not seen this group before more work needs to be done here and budget

Out of the five supported sites (Ngodwana, Vic Falls, Beitbridge, Cato Ridge and Inchope), 26 SWs in this age catagory were reached. Data was extracted from the following data sources (ONA, violence reporting database). 1 SWs reported violence to law enforcement. Almost 96% SWs are not reporting violence to law enforcement. From information out of the LGBTIQ Survey the following emerged as reasons for not reporting among the LGBTIQ : 1. Discrimination from law enforcement 2. Worked things out in the relationship 3. Taboo
All clients on this age category will receive communication on their rights

Out of the five supported sites (Ngodwana, Vic Falls, Beitbridge, Cato Ridge and Inchope). CRT stakeholders which include advocacy organisations, law enforcement were able to reach 103 SWs for accessing legal support.

title.narrative: Sex workers report changes in police behaviour

description.narrative: To identify if sex workers experience less violence and stigma and discrimination by police officers. This includes a measurement of increased confidence to report cases to the police and satisfaction with police service. Because the experience with police can significantly differ depending on gender of the sex worker, this outcome indicator will look at gender disaggregation.

comment.narrative: No activities were done to meet this target due to lockdown restrictions.
This outcome hasn’t been achieved in this period due to lockdown restrictions - this activity will be conducted in Q3 and Q4 as more community activities can be planned.

Out of the five supported sites (Ngodwana, Vic Falls, Beitbridge, Cato Ridge and Inchope). 38 Community leaders were trained on the Paralegal training and health and rights training.

title.narrative: Sex workers report a reduction in experienced stigma and discrimination by their community and by society

description.narrative: To identify a change in communities and society’s perspective on sex work contributing to a more supportive environment for sex work. This indicator refers to stigma and discrimination in relation to sex workers HIV status and/or gender/sexuality/profession and includes self-stigma.

comment.narrative: No activities were done to meet this target due to lockdown restrictions.
This activity is planned for Q3 and Q4, COVID pandemic permitting. It will be extremely valuable to understand how COVID has influenced stigma and discrimination in these key populations.
